text: My general rule of thumb: If you aren’t getting a lot of No’s to your request, you aren’t charging high enough.

elements.text: My general rule of thumb: If you aren’t getting a lot of No’s to your request, you aren’t charging high enough.

text:
Hi <@U01J3P3EVDL>. Here is my 2 cents:
*What is your biggest piece of advice for setting your rates as a beginner?*
Stay flexible. You’re almost definitely undercharging at the beginning, but that might be a rite of passage you have to go through if you don’t have a portfolio or other niche experience to point to. If you don’t have a portfolio to lean on, consider offering a discounted rate as a trial with new clients, but make it clear to the client that your rates will increase after a certain amount of articles or time together. It takes experimentation to find the right rate, and just know that your rates will inevitably change over time. The more experience you gain and the fuller your work pipeline, the way leeway you have to keep space for the types of projects that align with your prices, expertise, and values.

*What is the biggest no-no you can think of when setting your rates?*
Unless you’re just getting your bearings as a freelancer, avoid charging by the hour. If your goal is to build long-term relationships with clients or become a subject matter expert, you’ll become faster with each article. This not only lowers your hourly earning potential, it also punishes you for creating content that’s perfectly in tune with your client’s voice or industry’s lexicon. My preference is per-article billing. If you feel unsure about how to price an article, you can always do a behind-the-scenes calculation based on your baseline hourly rate. To do this, roughly estimate how long you think the article (including admin, research, writing, editing, and other other steps in the process) will take. Multiply that amount of time by the minimum you’d want to earn per hour. (Keep in mind your hourly rate should feel a little inflated compared to what you may earn at a standard hourly job.) Then you may even want to pad the figure a bit to take into account any unforeseeable hold-ups, costs of running your business, and taxes.


Happy to edit down or clarify as needed! Good luck with the article! <http://www.ashleesang.com|www.ashleesang.com>

text:
Curious on opinions of this group. Given the current (unstable) state of the world/economy, what are trends/opinions you’re seeing regarding tenure and “job hopping.” I was at a job for 2 years before being laid off (along w/ half the marketing dept) back in April. I did some freelance work over the summer and was lucky enough to have the inside track on a new role, where I started at the end of September.

I like my job a lot, but I am also trying to (slowly) pivot my career to be more focused on editor-type roles versus marketing-type roles, which was derailed by the lay-off and need to land a new position. How soon is too soon to think about taking a next step toward my goal? Any opinions, etc. would be welcome! :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text:

I did some freelance work over the summer and was lucky enough to have the inside track on a new role, where I started at the end of September.

I like my job a lot, but I am also trying to (slowly) pivot my career to be more focused on editor-type roles versus marketing-type roles, which was derailed by the lay-off and need to land a new position. How soon is too soon to think about taking a next step toward my goal? Any opinions, etc. would be welcome!

text:
First off, congrats on getting a new job in the middle of * all of this *  !

I don’t think there is such a thing as too soon—but there may be such a thing as ‘too late’. I’ve been privileged enough to be selective during the job search, and as a result I land in places that fit well where I can have relatively long tenures; but I’ve also had colleagues who lasted 2-3 months before going elsewhere, especially if they were trying to pivot/do something different/find a better fit.

In your case, sounds like you’re aiming for a pivot as well. So if you get an opportunity to do stuff that is more in line with what you want, why not go for it regardless? :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text:

I don’t think there is such a thing as too soon—but there may be such a thing as ‘too late’. I’ve been privileged enough to be selective during the job search, and as a result I land in places that fit well where I can have relatively long tenures; but I’ve also had colleagues who lasted 2-3 months before going elsewhere, especially if they were trying to pivot/do something different/find a better fit.

In your case, sounds like you’re aiming for a pivot as well. So if you get an opportunity to do stuff that is more in line with what you want, why not go for it regardless?

text:
Echoing Fio's sentiment above! I think the key thing is to be the *CEO of You* and working on that principle. If that means moving into a more editor-focused role, then use that as your north star to either:

:one: push to take on more editorial responsibilities within your current role

:two: see if you can free up some bandwidth to pick up some editing work

:three: keep the door open for roles that you _want_ and interview for them - doing this is really useful to see which skills you need / can build on to get where you want (bonus = you can try to train for these skills in your current role if possible, so it's a win-win for you and your current team bc you're growing your skills!)

Hope this is helpful and good luck! :raised_hands:

keep the door open for roles that you
want

and interview for them - doing this is really useful to see which skills you need / can build on to get where you want (bonus = you can try to train for these skills in your current role if possible, so it's a win-win for you and your current team bc you're growing your skills!)

Hope this is helpful and good luck!

text:
I totally agree with fio and Carmen. I’ve done a lot of job (s)hopping, and for me, some of it was because I started gaining clarity about what I do and don’t want, but another big part of it was that I would be exposed to opportunities where I knew I could help. People need your talents and abilities. So I would say, make sure you wrap up the important things before leaving a job, but don’t let the idea of “loyalty” keep you at a job you know you’re ready to or should move on from.

On another note, I’m the Training & Education Manager at a nonprofit called <https://aceseditors.org/resources/job-bank|ACES: The Society for Editing>, and we have a job bank especially for editing-specific roles!! We also offer editing and writing-related webinars, resources, etc.

Let me know if you have any questions or if I can help. :slightly_smiling_face:

attachments.title: Job Bank
attachments.fallback: ACES: The Society for Editing: Job Bank
